I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
knowledge: field of business ethics, important and related court cases
skills: how to analyze case studies and think through ethical scenarios
insights: running an ethical business is difficult

In this class, we learned how to analyze ethically questionable business decision using different theories of business conduct. We grounded our discussions and analysis in readings from different philosophers and cases and then discussed how to evaluate the decisions that were made. I developed my critical thinking skills, listening skills, argument-making skills, and expanded my knowledge about how to think about business decisions in an ethical framework.

Learned about theories of business ethics & business ethics applied to various areas (pharmaceuticals, finance, etc).  A good class if you want to get a sense for what business ethics and law would be like in practice.
I gained a lot of knowledge about different business-ethics perspectives, as well as some practical knowledge of ethical issues in finance, product liability, and pharma.
I developed a strong understanding of business ethics theory and a broader understanding of its application in various industry contexts and case law.

Learned a lot about shareholder theory, stakeholder theory, and some of the challenges corporations face and/or create when they decide to financially prioritize one group over another. Additional time was spent reviewing major court cases in business ethics and understanding the role of contracts.
A vague understanding of business ethic principles and frameworks

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: assignments were manageable, interesting, and open for personal direction; really fun material; lots of free-flowing class discussion
weaknesses: some readings were unnecessary/repetitive, generic feedback
areas for improvement: more lecturing and guidance by professor

The strengths of this course was certainly the discussion based format. Conversations were lively and the class was actively engaged in arguing different viewpoints with their reasonings grounded in the texts. The weaknesses of the course was the quantity and lack of diversity of opinions with the readings that were assigned. Oftentimes there would be many (6-8) readings assigned, most of which said very similar things about a topic at hand. That then led to the conversation in class being very one-sided and us agreeing with each other a lot of the time. I would have found it more useful if we were assigned 2 readings of different viewpoints and then we were to debate it out in class.

Strengths - the topics are very interesting.  Prof Landis is good.  

Weaknesses - too much reading.  It would be better to pick a few of the best readings so everyone would do all of them than assign ~200 pgs and have people do random readings.

I think the strength of this course are the readings and discussion, which are usually really interesting and thought-provoking. The weakness is probably the lack of structure. Discussion can feel a little repeated sometimes, because the same issues come up (stakeholder v. stockholder, etc.).

In terms of strengths, I really enjoyed the organization of class (Start with theory, then move into specific contexts). I also thought our class built a meaningful community and I liked how discussions were allowed to move in whatever direction the class took them. This made the class more engaging. In terms of weaknesses, the only one I would note is that some weeks readings were substantially longer than others.
I personally would have appreciated it if Professor Landis sent us some questions for discussion each week.

Professor Landis is totally unclear about his grading and really needs to be more upfront with rubrics and expectations. He also doesn't facilitate proper class discussion and it feels like everyone just talks at each other.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all succeeded

The readings and critical essay writing was especially useful to help ground our conversations in the virtual class environment. I wish that we spent more time in class discussing what each of us wrote about and debating out the topics, rather than just moving on -- and I think that a reduction in the quantity of readings (and being more selective about which were the most important ones) would allow for time to do that and for a more engaged class.
I thought the course ran smoothly given covid. I thought the use of short breaks was helpful.
Needs better discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yeah if looking for a fun and interesting "fifth class"

I would certainly recommend this course to someone who wanted to learn more about business decisions in an ethical framework. This class is great for understanding different theories that factor into making business decisions and for analyzing cases about past decisions. Someone who is prepared to do readings, have discussions, and ground their thoughts in the readings should certainly take this course.
It's a good EP&E seminar.  Not life changing, but I am glad I took it.  Helped me narrow down if I would want to go to law school.  The topics are thought provoking

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in corporate law and/or generally entering the corporate world. It's interesting to look at the issues that might come up in your career, and to think about potential approaches to resolving them. From a law standpoint, you're introduced to the legal solutions to these ethical issues  and about the overlap there (if any).
Yes! Course material and class discussions were super fascinating. Grading was also fair.
Don't take this course, it's a trap.
